ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned way more chemistry than I thought I would have. I feel like it was a lot of chemistry that did not play too many roles in cooking, but it still could be applied. The section of thermodynamics is when cooking was the most prevalent.
I didn't really learn anything.
I learned the basics of Chemistry and how it is applied when cooking.
I learned a lot of basic knowledge about chemistry related to food, and general chem and bio principles.
Basic mechanisms of how cooking works and the chemical reactions involved.
I developed a strong background into the chemistry behind many reactions in food and cooking.
I learned about the basic principals surrounding food and chemistry.

The course is split into six modules: atoms and molecules, carbohydrates, fat, protein, kinetics, and thermodynamics. I learned a lot about those six subjects and their applications to the world of food.

I learned a lot about how the intricacies of chemistry affect the visual presentation, flavor, and texture of food. The variety of different chemical reactions and phenomena presented in this course really deepened the way I look at food while cooking today. Learning about the maillard reaction or tenderization of meats, for example, are vital to understanding what happens at the molecular level while cooking.
This class taught me very practical and interesting information.
A better understanding of basic chemistry principles.
I relearned a lot of chemistry concepts from high school.
A basic understanding of intro chemistry
we learned about the chemistry that goes into cooking things
Science behind the food
The course mainly focuses on basic chemistry concepts, but also features applications to cooking.
I learned more about the chemistry behind food and cooking. I also learned how to better collaborate with students in a scientific setting.
I learned how to collaborate with classmates given the short time periods to take the in class exercises in this course.

Good class to get SC credit out of the way for more humanities-focused people. The class is not a gut. Be prepared for a lot of busy work, but if you show up to class and pay attention you can do fine in the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There's a lot of assignments in the course so one bad thing does not really matter. The weakness was that the lectures were normally boring and hard to pay attention to. With the inclass quizzes on lectures, it was sometimes hard to understand them if you didn't completely digest the material taught that day.
This course is really really easy but super boring. I didn't really learn anything.
I loved the experiments/demonstrations we had in class. Having more of these would make the class better.

I think the strengths involved the demonstrations and youtube videos that were chosen in class. 

I think the weaknesses involved the in-class quizzes. It is cool that you could work in groups but the minimum group size requirement added nothing and was consistently not fun.

They tried to make sections mandatory and would punish students who didn't go (ex: not releasing answers for practice exams, going over pset answers). Very unorganized and there were many times the TAs seemed like they didn't know what they were talking about or teaching. There were a couple of times that they gave answers to something or told us how to do a problem and it was actually wrong.

In class group assignments were at times difficult to follow. They may have been helpful with only groups of 2-3. The unit about coronavirus was particularly unhelpful. Problem sets were challenging, but helpful in preparation for exams.

A strength is the course format - the in class assignments foster class attendance and collaboration. They made me engage with the course material, which helped me understand all of the material and ask questions about what I didn't completely understand yet. Also, the research project was very interesting and made me interact with a lot of different ideas from many different classmates (which most larger classes don't do!)
This class is on a very interesting topic and overall was taught very well. However, the material was also taught very fast.

I discovered a love for chemistry through this course and expanded my knowledge exponentially. The main weakness was the limited number of demonstrations related specifically to food/cooking. It's much less of a food science gut and more of a standard chemistry lecture-based class that happens to mention food here and there.
The course had a lot of content and moved relatively fast. That being said I learned a lot and the teaching style was great but did not have too much time to reflect on what I just learned.
It was split into modules that helped the learning process. It was hard to hear sometimes.

Strengths: Easy to follow instructions and complete assignments
Weaknesses: Lectures are often a bit disorganized and hard to follow since no mic was used in a lecture setting so listening was often difficult.

This course was very disorganized. It was difficult to know what we were going to be assessed on. There were also many little assignments every week that seemed to come out of nowhere at unexpected intervals.
I thought there could have been more demos and in person real life experiments to make the class more interesting
interesting subject, not enough cooking
This course was organized effectively but could have engaged the students more with hands on activities. I wish there were more demos, especially involving food.

The lectures can become boring and the professor was very hard to hear.  It was easy to zone out.  To improve the course I would add more in class experiments or demos.  A strength was the in class exercises, because they forced everyone to attend class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. The grading scale is nice and I feel like there's some basic chemistry in this course that is good to know.
take as a science gut. It is a fair amount of work, but it is pretty easy to get an A grade given the way the grading in the class is set up.
No, it's boring and I didn't learn anything. Definitely a gut but not worth climbing up science hill twice a week.
Super easy science gut. They do in-class quizzes so you actually have to make the hike up science hill for class every time. If you show up it's an easy A

I would recommend this course to another student. I think it's a good way to get science credits as a non-stem major. The course is well taught. The homework and exams were well made and tested my knowledge accurately.
Yes, this is a really fun course if you are looking to learn about the basics of cooking!
There are a lot of assignments that you have to do but the grading is very much in your favor.
I would recommend this course to other students, but caution that prerequisite knowledge of chemistry is necessary.
Yes, I loved taking this course and the material was very relevant and beneficial to daily life.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this to another student looking for a stem course. It is a bit more work heavy than I first thought, but it is alright because the content is very interesting.

I recommend taking this course if you're interested in chemistry - I learned a ton! But if you're looking for a super easy science credit, look elsewhere; it was quite an intellectually stimulating course.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in beginner chemistry or anyone interested in cooking.
I would recommend. It was interesting.
Yes, very good distributional credit.
No. More trouble than it's worth.
Probably not I dont think it was very interesting and was not much different than normal chemistry
this was a great course
Yes! It is a good course for non-stem majors, although I do think that it could be better organised and facilitated.
Yes, as someone who didnt have a background in chemistry, the course was really interesting and taught chemistry in a practical way.
Yes. If the student is not a STEM major I believe this course does a good job exposing the student to scientific material without overwhelming the student with difficult scientific concepts.
I would recommend this course to someone who is looking for a science credit with lower difficulty and a lit workload.

Good class to get SC credit out of the way for more humanities-focused people. The class is not a gut. Be prepared for a lot of busy work, but if you show up to class and pay attention you can do fine in the course.

extras.title: CHEM 104 01 - Chemistry of Food and Cooking
